metadata.description: AMEGA cases perturbed with synonyms via LLM

data.case_str: A 58-year-old woman visits the ambulatory clinic with concerns about a recurrent tumor in her left bosom. She first noticed the tumor and indentation of the adjacent skin while bathing about 8 weeks ago. Over the past month, she has also observed a subtle withdrawal of the nipple with inflammation in the nipple area and hemorrhagic secretion, but no discomfort, as well as a small tumor in her left axilla. The patient has never given birth. She admits to skipping her scheduled radiograph for the past two years due to apprehension. Upon further history, she reveals that she went through menopause at age 51 and has been on hormone replacement therapy for the past 5 years to manage her post-menopausal symptoms. She has not experienced any weight loss, lethargy or abdominal or bone pain. Her sister was diagnosed with breast cancer at age 31, and her paternal grandmother had a history of uterine cancer. She has never smoked or consumed alcohol excessively.

A 65-year-old gentleman, a former tobacco user, visits the ambulatory clinic with complaints of relentless hacking and dyspnea for the past two months. He also reports unaccounted-for weight loss and occasional thoracic discomfort. Recently, he has started experiencing episodes of expectorating blood. His past medical history includes high blood pressure and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

A 65-year-old African American male presents to the ambulatory clinic with concerns about urological symptoms that have been deteriorating over the past six months. He reports a slow urological flow, increased frequency, nocturnal urination, and occasional difficulty initiating micturition. In the last two weeks, he has also noticed a mild discomfort and unease in his lower pelvic area. The patient mentions he has occasionally seen a hint of hematuria in his urine but has not experienced any pain while urinating. Upon further questioning, he reveals that he had undergone a sterilization procedure at age 45 and has a history of benign prostatic hypertrophy (BPH) diagnosed three years ago. He has no known history of sexually transmitted diseases. He admits to not having a prostate-specific antigen (PSA) test for the past four years due to fear of the results. He denies any significant weight loss, bone pain, or exhaustion. His father was diagnosed with prostate cancer at age 74, and an uncle had bladder cancer. He has never smoked and drinks alcohol occasionally, but in moderation.

A 60-year-old man presents to the ambulatory clinic with concerns about a modification in intestinal habits over the past two months, including intermittent bleeding in the feces and unexplained weight reduction. He also reports a recent feeling of exhaustion and occasional abdominal pain, mostly in the lower abdomen. The patient has a history of tobacco use and a stationary lifestyle. His family history is significant for colorectal cancer in his father, diagnosed at age 68. He has never undergone colonoscopy screening.

A 65-year-old gentleman presents to his principal healthcare doctor with painless gross hematuria. Upon further inquiry, he also complains about pyrexia, nocturnal diaphoresis and weight loss in the past few months. He has a history of high blood pressure, obesity and tobacco use. Family history is notable for renal cancer in his grandfather at the age of 72.

A 35-year-old man presents to his principal healthcare provider for a routine medical examination, as part of his new employment requirement. He reports feeling generally healthy and does not have any active grievances. However, when inquired about his habits, he admits to being a regular tobacco smoker for the past 15 years and consuming a diet primarily consisting of junk foods. He is also known to have type 2 diabetes mellitus, which he says is "mostly under control" with the help of oral antidiabetic medications. On further questioning, he reveals that he seldom engages in exercise, attributing it to his demanding office job that involves long hours at the desk. He has recently been feeling anxious due to personal issues and increased workload. He also mentions a history of chronic renal disease in his family, with his father being on dialysis. His body mass index indicates that he is obese. The patient reports that he recently used his father's automatic monitor to check his blood pressure and found it elevated.

A 55-year-old man with a history of hyperlipidemia and tobacco use is under evidence-based medical treatment (EBMT) for his chronic stable ischemic cardiac disease. Despite adherence to his pharmaceutical regimen, which includes high-intensity statins, beta-blockers, and aspirin, he presents with increasing episodes of thoracic distress and dyspnea. These symptoms now occur with minimal physical activity and occasionally at rest, indicating a potential deterioration of his condition. The distress is described as a compression-like sensation in the center of his thorax, intensifying during episodes of exertion or tension. Accompanying symptoms include lightheadedness and excessive diaphoresis, particularly noticeable during these episodes of distress. His symptoms have progressively worsened over the past few weeks. He has a family history of myocardial infarction, with his father having suffered one at the age of 61. Despite his pharmaceutical adherence, he confesses to not following a specific nutrition or exercise routine.

data.case_title: Management of acute chest pain / myocardial infarction
data.case_str: A 62-year-old man presents to the Urgent Care Department with a sudden onset of central thoracic pain that he describes as "constricting", which started approximately 2 hours ago while he was landscaping. The pain radiates to his left arm and is associated with breathlessness, perspiration, and queasiness. He has a history of high blood pressure and type 2 diabetes mellitus, both well-managed on medication. His only family history of note is his father, who died of a myocardial infarction at 65 years old.

A 57-year-old woman presents to the Urgent Care Department with a rapid onset of dyspnea that has been progressing over the past week. She describes difficulty reclining and finds herself needing to sit up to breathe better. This unease also intensifies when she leans forward. Over the past couple of days, she has noticed edema in her ankles and a pronounced distension in the veins of her neck. Furthermore, she reports a significant reduction in her ability to perform her usual tasks, attributing it to exhaustion and an increased convalescence time after any exertion. She mentions waking up in the middle of the night coughing and has also noticed a peculiar square-wave response during her recent doctor's visit when she was asked to perform the Valsalva maneuver. She has a medical history of high blood pressure and had a cardiac valve replacement a decade ago. Additionally, she underwent chemotherapy for breast cancer five years ago. There is a family history of ischemic heart disease: her mother suffered a myocardial infarction in her 60s.

A 59-year-old woman presents to the imaging department for the first follow-up computed tomography scan after surgical removal of the right upper lobe due to small cell pulmonary carcinoma. She has been given intravenous contrast medium one time before during a preoperative staging computed tomography scan. A few minutes after intravenous contrast administration, the patient experiences rapidly progressive severe hacking, vomiting and wheezing. She is very distressed and reports that she cannot breathe. There is a rash on her upper thorax, neck and face that was not present before the computed tomography scan. The patient has a history of asthma and atopic eczema.

A 45-year-old woman with a medical history of well-managed bronchial hyperreactivity and allergic nasal inflammation presents with increasing episodes of gasping, breathlessness, and thoracic constriction. These symptoms now occur with minimal physical activity and occasionally at repose, indicating a potential worsening of her bronchial hyperreactivity. The gasping is described as a high-pitched whistling sound, especially noticeable at night and early in the morning. Accompanying symptoms include a dry cough and feeling of constriction in the thorax. Her symptoms have progressively deteriorated over the past few days. She has a family medical history of bronchial hyperreactivity, with her mother having suffered from severe bronchial hyperreactivity. She has been adherent to her inhaler regimen, which includes low-dose inhaled corticosteroids and a long-acting beta-agonist but confesses to encountering recent stress and exposure to pollen.

data.case_title: Management of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
data.case_str: A 68-year-old woman presents to the outpatient department with a chronic cough and increasing distress in respiration over the past few months. She reports a long history of tobacco use, approximately a pack a day for 40 years, though she ceased tobacco use 5 years ago. She also mentions frequent episodes of bronchitis every winter for the last few years. On examination, she exhibits wheezing during exhalation and a prolonged expiratory phase. Her respiratory rate is elevated, and she appears to be using accessory muscles to respire.

A 52-year-old man with a remarkable medical record of alcoholic beverage abuse disorder and a recent diagnosis of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) presents with multiple signs suggestive of advanced hepatic illness. He reports persistent lethargy and significant body mass reduction over the past few months. On assessment, he exhibits abdominal swelling, indicative of fluid accumulation, a common consequence of liver scarring. Additionally, he has developed icterus, a clear indicator of liver malfunction. Skin-related findings include spider-like blood vessel growths on his torso and limbs, as well as reddening of the palms. He has a long history of alcoholic drink consumption, averaging over two decades, and admits to using non-prescription analgesics regularly for chronic dorsal pain. He leads an inactive lifestyle and has no familial medical history of hepatic disease.

A 68-year-old woman presents to the Urgent Care Department with decreased urinary output and exhaustion over the past two days. She has been experiencing postural lightheadedness and arrhythmias, especially when standing up quickly. She mentions a recent severe episode of loose stools, after which she did not adequately replenish fluids. She has a medical history of high blood pressure and type 2 diabetes mellitus, managed with medication. Recently, she started taking NSAIDs for articular pain. She also complains of mild breathlessness and peripheral swelling.

A 55-year-old man with a medical history of hyperlipidemia and tobacco use presents with worries related to his persistent renal disease (CKD). He has been diagnosed with CKD stage 3 due to long-standing high blood pressure and type 2 diabetes mellitus, which are well-managed with pharmaceuticals. Recently, he has been experiencing increased exhaustion, occasional nocturnal urination, and itchiness. He reports a gradual increase in serum creatinine levels over the past few months. He has a family medical history of CKD, with his mother having been diagnosed in her late 60s. He admits to a diet high in processed foods and has not been adhering to recommended liquid intake.

A 62-year-old gentleman presents to the principal healthcare clinic for a scheduled check-up. He reports enhanced dryness, recurrent micturition, and a recent inexplicable mass reduction of 10 pounds over the past two months. He has a history of high blood pressure and a stationary lifestyle. His family history is notable for type 2 diabetes mellitus in his mother, and there's a known history of cardiovascular disease in the family. He is obese, with a recent increase in mass prior to the inexplicable mass reduction. His current medications include lisinopril for high blood pressure. He has no known sensitivities.

A 30-year-old man presents to the Urgent Care Department complaining of stomach discomfort that began around 10 hours ago. The discomfort initially started around his belly button but has since relocated to the right lower quadrant (RLQ) of his belly. He describes the discomfort as a constant, mild soreness that worsens with movement. Accompanying symptoms include loss of appetite, queasiness, and a low-grade fever. He denies any vomiting, diarrhea, or urinary symptoms. The patient has no significant past medical or surgical history. He is not on any medications and has no known drug allergies. There is no family history of digestive diseases. On examination, his vital signs are stable, but he exhibits sensitivity in the RLQ on palpation.

A 72-year-old man presents to the Urgent Care Department with abrupt onset of right-sided debility and difficulty articulating. The signs were first noticed upon waking up, approximately 3 hours before presenting to the medical facility. The patient has a medical past of well-managed high blood pressure and type 2 diabetes mellitus. There is a significant familial history of cerebral vascular disease, with his father having experienced a cerebrovascular accident at the age of 65.

A 32-year-old person presents to the facility with symptoms persisting for three weeks. The medical manifestations include pyrexia, lethargy, generalized eruption, unintentional weight loss, and occasional nocturnal diaphoresis. The patient also reports a history of multiple unprotected sexual encounters and intravenous substance abuse. There is no significant medical or family history reported. Additionally, the patient mentions experiencing frequent cephalalgias, muscle and joint pains, and has noticed swollen lymph nodes. They also describe episodes of nausea and diarrhea within the same time frame. Despite the absence of any chronic conditions, the patient expresses concern about the sudden onset and persistence of these symptoms.

A 35-year-old man presents to his general medical doctor for a compulsory medical examination required by his new employer. The patient appears overall well but reports a history of regular tobacco smoking for the past 15 years and a diet predominantly consisting of junk food. He has a known history of type 2 diabetes, which he manages with oral antidiabetic medications. Due to his inactive job, he admits to a lack of regular exercise. The patient expresses experiencing increased levels of anxiety recently, stemming from both personal problems and heightened demands at work. He mentions a family history of chronic renal disease and his concern about being obese, as indicated by his body mass index. During the consultation, the patient reveals feelings of persistent melancholy and a noticeable loss of interest in activities that he once found enjoyable. He initially attributed these feelings to the pressure in his life but now recognizes them as overwhelming and persistent. In addition to the primary concerns, the patient also notes occasional disturbances in his sleep pattern, fluctuating appetite, and a sense of exhaustion that seems disproportionate to his level of physical activity. He mentions struggling with focus at work and feeling unusually indecisive, even in mundane day-to-day decisions.
